results.title: Science and money
results.creator_credit: BBC, Michael Coyle and Mike Milne
results.brief_description: While this program is about British coinage, the information on coin alloys and the reasoning for notes versus coins remains relevant. Shows coins actually being tested from the basic alloy through the entire production process.

results.title: Science and agriculture: the soy bean
results.brief_description: A study of the interdependence of science and agriculture in modern life. In a fairly detailed study of the soy bean, its cultivation in China and the USA is shown; the processes of extracting soy bean oil, and the preparation and use of soy bean by-products in the home and in industry are shown.

results.title: Sci-five
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, Nicholas Alexander, Russell Porter and Roger Seccombe
results.brief_description: Sci-five is a film about five very different young Australians who share an absorbing curiousity about the world. It contains interviews with Darren Kelly, Geraldine Milroy, Robert Sinclair, Lindy Coulson and Tim Allen. Each of the five has been a finalist in the BHP Science Prize and their projects provide a focus around which we explore their lives in more detail. The film aims to disprove the common assumption that science is “too hard and too boring” an option for young people. It has no objective commentary, using instead the insights of the teenage scientists themselves. A mosaic structure juxtaposes and intercuts their stories to create a rfascinating documentation of ideas and motives.

results.title: Schubert and his music
results.brief_description: Depicts life in the early 19th century and the people and places of Vienna which have had an important influence on the music of Franz Schubert. Shows Schubert’s birth place, the church where he sang as a boy and where, later, his music was performed, life in Vienna and the group of singers, painters, poets and actors who were part of the romantic movement of this period. Excerpts from the following are included in the film: Valses Nobles, Opus 77; Moment Musicaux, Opus 94; the First and Second Movements of the Symphony No. 8 “Unfinished”; “Der Lindenbaum”; the First Movement of the Quintet in A Major, Opus 114 “The Trout”; and “Serenade”.

results.title: Schools working with curriculum frameworks
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch, David Ferris and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Trevor Lunn introduces a panel including Dr. Max Stephens, Anne Gooding, Mary Weaven, Enid Mayfield, Geoff Whyte, Denis Cunningham and Geoff Burt who explain how the key ideas and issues of Curriculum Frameworks are being addressed by Schools. This panel of teachers and regional consultants discuss several specific frameworks areas.

results.title: Schools out
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre, Ross Campbell and Alex Rappel
results.brief_description: Examines three innovative schools - Brinsley Road an annexe to Camberwell High school, Collingwood Community school, and Swinburne Community school. Students and teachers comment on the differences between these and traditional schools, and the relationships between pupils, teachers, and the community.

results.title: Schools and school discipline. Tape 2.= Communication and motivation.
results.brief_description: Dr. William Glasser, founder of the Institute of Reality Therapy, discusses motivation in schools. Besides making sure that every student believes he or she has a chance in school, Dr. Glasser also stresses, through related examples, the inherent motivational qualities of courtesy and laughter, and the importance of communication with students through his use of classroom meetings.

results.title: Schoolboy, sailor, saint
results.creator_credit: De Filmfabriek, Laika Films, Studio 1, Bavo Defurne, Karel Doing and Anne Quirynen
results.brief_description: ‘Schoolboy, Sailor, Saint’ is a compilation of three short films (Saint, Particularly now, In spring and Sailor) from Belguim film maker Bavo Defurne, which explore gay desire, while paying homage to artists such as Jean Genet, Herbert List and Pierre and Gilles. Shot on b/w super-8 and using little sound, ‘Saint’ (1996) is both an indirect tribute to Genet’s homoerotic classic, “Un Chant d’Amore”, and a meditation on the violent death of Saint Sebastian. ‘Particularly now, in Spring’ (1995) is an idealised vision of youth which recounts a seventeen year old boy’s optimistic musings about his future, and the friendships he has forged with the boys at his sports club. The films visual style is influenced by pre-war German art, and by gay Jewish photographer Herbert List. The final film, ‘Sailor’ (1997) is a simply told tale of a boy’s yearning and unrequited love for a sailor, whose adventures at sea are imagined by the wistful boy. Shot on video, ‘Sailor’s‘ vibrant colours and highly stylised backdrops recall the luscious, camp archetypes of gay artists Pierre and Gilles. Cast includes: (Saint) Olaf Nollen, Alex van Stratum (Particularly now, in spring) Olaf Nollen (Sailor) Joram Schurmans, Tom de With.

results.title: School support centres
results.creator_credit: Corporate Relations Unit, Western Metro Region and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Kevin Collins, Chief General Manager, Schools Division, describes the development and role of the School Support Centres and their aims and objectives in assisting the school community and teachers with a range of services and courses which will ultimately provide greater benefits to students. Features examples from a number of different School Support Centres.
